acf.title: game-price-tracker
acf.tech_stack: ES6+ JavaScript, React, Redux, Node, MongoDB, Jest
acf.tech_stack_full: JavaScript, HTML, CSS, React, Redux, Node, Express, MongoDB, REST API, Jest
acf.short_description: A full stack progressive web app, which alerts users to price drops in the Sony PlayStation store. I reverse-engineered Sony's internal REST API. Extensive testing via Jest.
acf.long_description:
The app allows a user to search for a PlayStation game, and to submit their email address to sign up for a notification if the game goes on sale. The game and user info are stored in a MongoDB collection as a 'price alert.'

Once a day, the app's back-end iterates through the database and queries the PlayStation store, comparing prices to determine if the game is on sale. If the game is on sale, the user will receive an email. If the game hasn't gone on sale for 18 weeks, the user's price alert is deleted, and the user is invited to sign up again.

acf.title: youtube-mixtape
acf.tech_stack_full: jQuery, jQuery-UI, Node, Express, REST API, Spotify API, YouTube API
acf.short_description: A new music app using Spotify to generate a list of similar artists, and YouTube to find and play their songs.
acf.long_description:
The app first uses Spotify's API to validate your search as a known artist. Immediately after this validation, the app uses YouTube's API to search for a short, music category video result, and begins playing.

Now that music is playing, the app continues to make calls to Spotify's API with a search algorithm to generate a list of similar artists based on one or more common genres. Currently, the results are presented by the number of common genres. Find this code in './views/js/searchSpotify.js'

As each video finishes playing, the app advances to the next artist result, and retrieves a new video result from YouTube.

The app also offers the ability to create/view/edit a YouTube playlist. Get started with this feature by clicking + Add to Mixtape. Note that to save your playlist, you will be required to sign into your Google account.

TL;DR
The app chains calls to Spotify's API to generate a hierarchical list of similar artists, and uses YouTube's API to find and play corresponding music videos. The user can also create and modify a "mixtape" via drag-and-drop.
acf.secondary_text: Drag and drop artist results to change mix order. (Not yet supported for touch devices.), Remove a specific artist result with the X button., Directly clicking an artist result will trigger a YouTube search and begin playing a resulting video., Show/hide video player., Select the Lock artist button to keep listening to videos from the same artist., The app keeps track of your listen history and avoids replaying the same song in a given session., Quietly retrieves an access token to Spotify's API via a back-end Node/Express server. (From a UX perspective, I feel this is better than requiring users to sign-in to their Spotify accounts just to try out the app.), Responsive design.

acf.title: this-vs-that
acf.tech_stack_full: JavaScript, jQuery, HTML, CSS, Bootstrap, REST API, Autosuggestion API
acf.short_description: An automated Google search, which appends commonly used conjunction keywords, (i.e. "vs"), and chains the resulting Google autocomplete suggestions.
acf.long_description: The app searches through each of Google's autosuggestions, creating a chain of results that terminates upon finding a duplicate result.
acf.secondary_text: A search history, which allows the user to revisit their results without additional API calls., Clickable results., Each result item is a link to an actual Google search., The exact search terms include the previous result, plus the conjunction keyword.

acf.title: tic-tac-toe-javascript
acf.short_description: The classic, with custom animations and a responsive game board
acf.long_description: Programming Tic-Tac-Toe seems like a developer's right of passage. I reached a workable game fairly quickly, so I took the design and UX a little further with animates x's and o's via <canvas> and a responsive game board.
acf.secondary_text: It should let me play a game of Tic Tac Toe with the computer., It should let me play a game of Tic Tac Toe with another human., It should let me pit the computer against itself., It should keep score of consecutive games., It should scale the size of the scoreboard to the viewport., It should animate the drawing of X's and O'x., It should display a "start" screen, like on an old video game.

acf.title: simon-the-game
acf.short_description: My interpretation of the 1980's memory game in JavaScript

acf.title: pomodoro-clock
acf.short_description: Work/break timer cycle with a nifty minimal UI
acf.long_description: My implementation of a Pomodoro clock. Click the settings icon to play with faster intervals (useful for demo).

acf.title: javascript-calculator
acf.short_description: A simple calculator coded in JS, emulating the appearance of a TI-108
acf.long_description: I remember using the TI-108 in elementary school. The teacher had a big box of these calculators, which were only made available for special math assignments. Well, now you can enjoy the patriotic color scheme of this classroom classic whenever the mood strikes!
acf.secondary_text: Because we have the benefit of using this TI-108 in a powerful modern browser, the font-size of the screen will automatically decrement to accommodate as many digits as are required. (So there's no pesky truncation of long numbers.)

acf.title: winter-beer-conditions-checker
acf.tech_stack_full: JavaScript, jQuery, CSS, HTML, REST API, OpenWeather API
acf.short_description: Checks the weather, date, and time to determine if it's time for a Snow Cap.
acf.long_description: As winter approaches, so does the most wonderful of seasonal beers... Pyramid Snow Cap.
